messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Gregory Weidman <delrayva@...>
wrote:
>
> Dear Anthony,
>
> I'm having trouble seeing how to work a strictly phonetic
>approach in real life even within my own writing. My
>family and I discussed recently the different
>pronunciations of the "t" in "train" that we have among
>us. The difference is that sometimes TOT is used, and
>sometimes CHURCH is used. Listening to myself carefully
>in this and similar words, I find that most of the time
>use TOT, but on occasion I will start this word with
>CHURCH. Should I write the exact same word differently
>depending on which pronunciation I use in a particular
>context? Certainly not, since I intend the same phoneme
>in each context. Writing this word phonetically just
>introduces confusion.

Dear Greg,

I do not mean to suggest a purely phonetic implementation of QS but
what you bring up is very much worth addressing. Indeed I have seen
texts (Aesop's fables in particular) using Cheer for "tr" through out.
This disturbed me at first. But the only important thing is *I could
read it just as well as Tut+Roar*

To get to your observation let me digress into an issue I have that
may help. It's about vowels but please bear with me. People with my
accent do not differentiate between Ox, Ah and Awe. I usually make the
sound Ox for all such words but sometimes if I pay close attention to
my own speech I notice that I'll sometimes say a word with the Ox
sound and sometimes the same word has what might pass for an Ah sound.
Because I *mostly* use the Ox sound, I must *just* use Ox otherwise I
might write "tot" sometimes as Tut+On+Tut(which is fine) but sometimes
as Tut+Awl+Tut which may sound right to me but would not be for others
(eg most British). An especial disaster if I were writing about a tot
who was taught Quickscript.

So to your issue: in a *particular* word, whatever sound "tr" makes
*most* of the time indicates the letter a person should use *all* of
the time. Just as you say: a person should spell a given word the same
way every time even if on some occasions it sounds slightly different.
But just because a person pronounces one word beginning with "tr" as
Cheer does not necessarily mean he pronounces every "tr" word that
way: it's important that a particular word be spelled consistently but
not that one slavishly substitute a leading "tr" with the letter Cheer
for every word. So "train" may be Church+Roar+... and "truck"
Tut+Roar+... but they both have to stay that way.

So I suggest QS is not in fact a literal phonetic transcription of
actual speech but that a word's spelling is determined by its
idealized pronunciation in the speakers accent. It is this
"semi-phonetic" nature of the script that is causing so much
discussion but I argue this is 1. how it is in practice used and 2.
what Read meant (in much of the book anyway) and 3. the only workable
way to do it.


> Other consonant problems are one of emphasis. When I
>want to emphasize the word "Matter," I will use TOT in the
>middle of it. When I am not emphasizing the word, I use
>"DEAD" in the middle of it. Should I spell the same word
>differently depending on whether I am emphasizing it? I
>hardly think so. (Just as a note -- I use DEAD in the
>middle of "Matters" almost exclusively, even when
>emphasizing it.) In each case, the same phoneme is
>communicated, even if they are phonetically distinct.

Intentionally varying spelling for emphasis is an intriguing idea. It
maybe a valid literary technique just as writing in dialect is (or was
anyway). If so, it is a literary tool authors would have in
Quickscript that they do not in Traditional Orthodoxy. It's really
something to think about and not automatically rule out. Building a
new system allows one potentially to break free of old restrictions if
they have no value and what you point out as a problem would also
allow a conveyance of information (in this case emotional content)
that is impossible in TO. In that it would be quite valuable and
really worth considering.


> As an aside, has anyone else noticed that Read uses THITHER instead
> of THOTH in the words "with" and "without" on page 11 of QM? Is this
> really the way he pronounced these words? I can't even get my mouth
>to form that sound in the middle of "without."

It is indeed how he pronounced "with"
You'll find that RP has wild differences from American English
which is what makes my comparison of a story written in each accent so
compelling when they turn out spelled virtually identically.



You can see how Kingsley pronounced any given word in the Cambridge
dictionary as Oxford-Cambridge is the high guardian of Received
Pronunciation English (called RP).

http://www.dictionary.cambridge.org/

Incidentally, if some sort of phonetic or phonemic spelling is *not*
used, be prepared to QS spell the way that dictionary pronounces
things. In particular, you and I are going to have to use THITHER in a
lot of words we don't want to because spelling is going to be fixed to
the way Kingsley did it.



>Of course, that might explain why he needed an
>abbreviation for "with" when WOW-IT-THOTH is so easy to
>write. I don't think this observation helps my argument
>at all, but it is an interesting point to consider as we
>discuss this.

You hit a good point and it turns out to be quite relevant to your
"tr" issue. Kingsley also insists we spell "the" with a lone THITHER
because if we did not we would have to change that last vowel from
UTTER to EAT all the time.

Forgive me as you already probably know all this but here are some
useful links:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimal_pair


Best,
-Tony
